editorial.name: Daniel Revachat
editorial.bio: Daniel is a DPhil student in Experimental Psychology. A member of the first Reuben cohort back when he did his MSc, he witnessed the Reuby magazine steadily grow in splendor - its editorial team, the quality of its publications, and its role as the voice of the people of Reuben College. Issue 3 embodies this very friendship, craft, and vision - in each page and every word.

editorial.name: Eliza Rayner
editorial.bio: Eliza is a DPhil student on the Interdisciplinary Biosciences DTP studying the evolution of antibiotic resistance. The Reuby was one of the first things she got involved in when she joined Reuben College three years ago, and she hasn’t looked back since! Every time a new issue comes around, she really looks forward to the chance to take on a creative project and bring the amazing work of our contributors to life.

editorial.name: Jayroop Ramesh
editorial.bio: Words unsaid are the window to a person’s soul. Wrongly so, perhaps, but Jay believes words of all shapes and sizes are beautiful. In these days of algorithmically generated lorem ipsums, however inspired by the collective knowledge of humanity, Jay aims to hold on to the spark of people’s innate desire to create and communicate. And that’s what The Reuby does, share the wonderful words - worry warts and all - of Reubenites!

editorial.name: Puyu Wang
editorial.role: IT Officer and Webmaster (Maintainter of this Website)
editorial.bio: Puyu is yet another DPhil student in Engineering Science at the Oxford e-Research Centre. Puyu is trying to help computers grasp the nuances of human culture. For more information, please visit Puyu's website at https://puyuwang.org. For Reuby, Puyu vibe coded a website where all past issues—as well as the current one—are easily accessible.

editorial.name: Katherine Faulkner
editorial.bio: Katherine is a DPhil student working at the intersection of biology and palaeontology. She likes writing and drawing, so naturally, she ended up at The Reuby. Katherine believes everyone should have a space to share their story, so make that space count!

editorial.name: Hannah Cole
editorial.bio: Hannah, a once inspiring journalist turned criminologist, joined The Reuby to feel connected again to her reporting roots––though she is not a writer, but merely the face behind the Reuby Instagram. When she’s not investigating crimes, Hannah enjoys being in creative and journalistic environments. The Reuby offered the perfect opportunity to engage in a publication exploring the unique intersection of niche news, art, culture, and technology stories. Hannah probably will not leave her life of crime behind, but The Reuby makes a convincing argument for returning to journalism.

editorial.name: Shreya Ganguli
editorial.bio: Shreya is an MSt Global and Imperial History student at Reuben College and one of the editors of The Reuby. In particular, she edits pieces on humanities-related subjects, which she especially welcomes in such a STEM-heavy environment. As Shreya is only on a 9-month programme, she leaves Reuben College and The Reuby in a couple of weeks and will immensely miss the camaraderie of the Monday evening team meetings. She has really enjoyed working with the team and writers this year and looks forward to reading future editions!

editorial.name: Prenika Anand
editorial.bio: "Addressing the 21st-century challenges for 'human'ity"; those words are my first memories of the Reuben ethos. Humans of Reuben in The Reuby is our way of celebrating each human in that quest, and their experiences within a community they shaped and that shaped them. The alumni edition this year adds new stories to the student experience and for all alumni, a revisit to shared memories, meals, laughter, and conversations.

advisors.name: Professor Dinosaur
advisors.bio: We have been Dining with Dinosaurs.
